awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Role of Convective Momentum Transport for the Madden-Julian Oscillation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to understand the role of convective momentum transport (CMT) in the lifecycle of the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO).  The MJO is an envelope of organized convection that propagates from the Indian Ocean to the Pacific Ocean and constitutes the dominant form of intraseasonal precipitation and atmospheric circulation variability in the tropics. The MJO influences a variety of tropical weather and climate phenomena,including tropical cyclones (affecting hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico), the onset and intraseasonal fluctuations of the monsoons and rainfall over Asia, Australia, Africa, and the Americas, and the onset of El Nino events.  CMT refers to the vertical transport of horizontal momentum that takes place due to the updrafts and downdrafts in convective clouds.  Traditional theories of the MJO have emphasized the role of convective clouds in transporting heat and moisture, and in driving large-scale circulations through latent heat release.  But some recent studies suggest that CMT may play a critical role for the development of the MJO circulation through a two-way dynamical interaction between the MJO and convectively coupled equatorial waves (CCEWs) within the much larger MJO envelope.  Through detailed analysis of newly available datasets, including those produced during the Dynamics of the MJO (DYNAMO) field campaign, the principal investigators seek to achieve a comprehensive characterization of CMT associated with the MJO, and thereby improve our understanding of the role of cumulus effects on MJO development.

The MJO is of practical as well as scientific interest, given the many climate and weather impacts of MJO activity.  The work performed here has the potential to improve MJO forecasts, through the development of parameterizations through which the effects of CMT can be included in numerical models used to produce long-range predictions of the MJO. por.por_cntn:
Despite its tremendous impacts on weather extremes worldwide, the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) remains poorly represented in current climate models. Significant efforts have been made in the community towards improved understanding of key MJO physics. While most of previous studies focused on thermodynamic processes of the MJO, this project investigates collective upscale impacts from multi-scale convective elements on MJO circulation, namely the convective momentum transport (CMT).

By analyzing parameterized CMT output from a high-resolution reanalysis dataset, it is illustrated that subgrid convection-induced CMT in MJO zonal wind component exhibits a well-defined three-layer vertical structure: positive (negative) u-wind tendency near the surface, negative (positive) from the lower- to mid- troposphere, and positive (negative) in the upper troposphere within and to the west (east) of the MJO convection, in agreement with meso-scale CMT structure associated with the MJO based on simulations by a global cloud-system resolving model. This subgrid- or meso-scale CMT profile tends to damp MJO circulation in the free atmosphere, meanwhile reduce the MJO eastward propagation speed. The vertical momentum transport for the MJO by convectively coupled equatorial waves (CCEWs), as previously emphasized by several idealized model studies, however, turns out to be weak as indicated by the reanalysis.

Further evidence of the subgrid CMT on propagation of the MJO as suggested by the above analyses is further illustrated by numerical experiments based on the new generation GFDL atmospheric GCM (AM4). While the control experiment based on AM4 fails to capture the observed eastward propagation of the MJO, coherent eastward propagating MJO signals emerge when the CMT effect is turned off in the cumulus parameterization module of AM4. Significant changes in simulated MJO winds due to CMT effects are noted in AM4 simulations. Considering that a coupled version of standard AM4 with an ocean model can realistically produce the observed eastward propagation of the MJO, it implies that in the reality the damping effect on the MJO propagation due to the CMT tends to be overcome by the air-sea interaction effect.

Momentum budget analyses of westerly wind events (WWEs) associated with the MJO during the Dynamics of the Madden–Julian Oscillation (DYNAMO) field campaign were also conducted in this project. It is illustrated that low-level westerly acceleration during the active MJO is largely maintained by the pressure gradient force, while is partly canceled by meridional advection of the zonal wind. Meanwhile, westerly acceleration in the mid-troposphere is largely attributed by vertical advection of u-wind, suggesting a nonlinear process during evolution of the WWEs associated with the MJO. A detailed case study further illustrates that some individual WWE events, for example, the second WWE event associated with the DYNAMO MJO event in late November, can be induced by horizontal advection of u-wind associated with CCEW activity. This study uniquely contributes to the DYNAMO project by providing insights into dynamical processes involved in the wind evolution associated with the DYNAMO MJO events.

This project provided training for a postdoc researcher. It also partially supported the PI (Jiang)’s great efforts in co-leading the WCRP-WWRP/THORPEX YOTC MJO Task Force - GEWEX GASS MJO model inter-comparison project (2012-2015), as well as his contribution to a variety of collaborative research activities.
